headline: Spanish PM, defence minister phones tapped, presidency says
summarized_story:
Spain said, on Monday, that the mobile phones of Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez and Defence Minister Margarita Robles were tapped using Pegasus spyware in an “illicit and external” intervention.
“It is not a supposition, they are facts of enormous gravity,” the minister of the presidency, Felix Bolanos, said, confirming the news.
Bolanos said that Sanchez’s phone had been tapped in May 2021 and Robles’ in June of the same year.
“There is no evidence that there was another tapping after those dates.”Pegasus spyware silently infiltrated mobile phones to extract data or activate a camera or microphone to spy on their owners.
Catalan separatists had accused Spain’s intelligence services of using spyware to snoop on their mobile phones, reviving tensions with Sanchez’s minority leftist government, which relied on their support to pass legislation.

headline: War: Russia suffers another major blow amid battle with Ukraine

Sunday Dare, minister of sports and youth development, also announced the constitution of two separate committees to investigate the incident — with the panels’ findings yet to be made public.

The youths, who started the procession from the MASSOB leader’s House in Owerri, marched through the streets, carrying different placards, with inscriptions such as “Power to the Youths, Support Yahaya Bello”, “Youths Can Also Lead”, and “Yahaya Bello for the Youths”, among others.

headline: British Member of Parliament to resign for Watching Porn in Parliament
summarized_story:
A Conservative British Member of Parliament, Neil Parish, has announced that he will resign after admitting twice watching pornography in the House of Commons.
Parish told the BBC the first time he viewed the explicit material was an accident after searching online for farm vehicles.
The Government of Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, is engulfed in numerous scandals, just days ahead of crucial local elections.
The Prime Minister himself has been fined by police for breaching his own Covid rules during the 2020 lockdown, and faces an investigation into whether he misled Parliament about parties in Downing Street.
We support his decision to step down as our Member of Parliament.”

headline: Asiwaju Tinubu Receives APC Presidential Nomination Forms -
summarized_story:
The National Leader of the All Progressives Congress and Frontline Presidential Aspirant, Asiwaju Bola Ahmed Tinubu, has received his Expression of Interest and Nomination Forms to enable him participate in the Presidential Primaries of the Party.
Asiwaju Tinubu who just returned to the Country after performing the lesser Hajj (Umrah) in Mecca received the forms from Lagos State Governor, Babajide Olusola Sanwoolu.
His support groups led by former Secretary to the Government of the Federation, Babchir Lawal, and Senator Dayo Adeyeye purchased the forms for him on Friday afternoon.
The Party’s Presidential Primaries will hold between the 30th of May and 1st of June.
The Party’s Presidential contest has become increassingly crowded in recent days with the declaration of the Vice President Yemi Osinbajo, Governors Yahaya Bello of Kogi State and Kayode Fayemi of Ekiti State, Senators Ibikunle Amosun and Chris Ngige, Minister of Transportation, Rotimi Amaechi, Minister of Education, Chkwuemeka Nwajiuba and Others.

headline: Nigeria: Despite Oil Prices Rising Above $100 Per Barrel, Impact on Budget will Be Negligible, RenCap Says
summarized_story:
A new report by Renaissance Capital (RenCap), a frontier market investment company, has stated that despite crude oil prices at over $100 per barrel, the impact on Nigeria’s fiscal position would remain negligible due to petrol subsidy payments and falling oil production by the country.
“This implies that Nigeria has a $3 billion net benefit for every $10 per barrel change to the oil price (Brent),” it stated.
The federal government recently increased the 2022 subsidy budget from N443 billion to N4 trillion, after it shifted the planned removal of what it terms under-recovery by 18 months.
RenCap said in the report, “An 80 per cent increase in the oil price, from $41/bbl to $72/bbl, reduced the budget deficit by about 1 ppt only.
We attribute the widening of the deficit in 2021, despite the high oil price, to the fall in production that countered the price effect.
